Elliot C. Shaw, Rachael Fowler, Sara Ohadi, Michael James

Title:
Explaining the worldwide distributions of two highly mobile
species: Cakile edentula and C. maritima
Abstract:
Aim: To determine the number of successful colonisation
events that have occurred throughout the world and the extent to which
introduced locations differ climatically from the native sources.
Location: Worldwide Taxon: Sea-Rockets (Cakile spp.) Methods: We used a
high throughput sequencing, genome skimming approach combined with
Bayesian Inference phylogenetics to examine variation within entire
chloroplast genomes and regions of nuclear ribosomal DNA within native
and introduced regions. Databases were used to compare climates at the
first recorded overseas sites with the locations from which samples from
significant clades were collected. Results: At least seven clades have
invaded different regions of the world. In most cases we were able to
identify their source regions and climates. The environmental
bottlenecks differed in intensity, with some indicating that clades had
a very broad innate environmental tolerance. We found clear evidence of
hybridation Â– specifically chloroplast capture - between two species in
Australia, Main Conclusions: Cakile species provide an excellent
opportunity to study replicated climate adaptation trajectories, but the
relative importance of tolerance and local adaptation require further
investigation. Interpretations of invasion trajectories based solely on
species-level databases can be highly misleading.
